facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 765 of 1964 before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 765 of1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 23, 1963 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 24 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated April 23, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 24 of 1963.

facts.text: Election petition filed by respondent No. 1 Harikishan Singh challenging validity of appellant Bhaiyalal's election.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of an Election petition filed by respondent No. 1, Harikishan Singh, challenging the validity of the election of the appellant, Bhaiyalal,

facts.text: Election held in February 1962 for reserved seat in Berasia Constituency, district Sehore, Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: in a reserved seat in the Berasia Constituency in the district of Sehore in Madhya Pradesh. The election in question was held in February, 1962

facts.text: Appellant Bhaiyalal declared duly elected on 26th February 1962 after polling highest votes.

anchor.surface_text: at this election the appellant, respondent No. 1, and three others offered themselves as candidates. The appellant was declared duly elected on the 26th February, 1962

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was next rival to appellant in votes.

anchor.surface_text: since he had polled the highest number of votes. His next rival was respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Appellant filed nomination paper on 19th January 1962 before Returning Officer at Sehore declaring himself member of Chamar scheduled caste.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had filed his nomination paper on the 19th January, 1962 before the Returning Officer at Sehore and had declared that he was a member of the Chamar scheduled caste

facts.text: Returning Officer accepted appellant's declaration of belonging to Chamar scheduled caste.

anchor.surface_text: of the State of Madhya Pradesh in relation to Sehore district. This declaration was accepted by the Returning Officer.

facts.text: Respondent contended that Dohar caste not recognised as scheduled caste for Sehore and Raisen districts.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 contended that Dohar caste was not recognised as the scheduled caste for the district of Sehore and Raisen, and so, the Returning Officer had improperly

facts.text: Appellant belonged to Dohar caste according to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: and illegally accepted the declaration of the appellant as one belonging to the Chamar scheduled caste. Since the appellant did not belong to the scheduled caste

facts.text: Appellant urged election petition not maintainable due to no security deposit of Rs. 2000.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the appellant urged that the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was not maintainable inasmuch as he had not deposited the security of Rs. 2,000

facts.text: Election Tribunal found in favour of respondent No. 1 on caste issue and against appellant on security deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal considered the oral evidence adduced by the parties, examined the documents on which they respectively relied, and found in favour of respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Election Tribunal declared appellant's election invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the election petition was allowed and the appellants election declared invalid.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Madhya Pradesh High Court, appeal dismissed on 23rd April 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision of the Election Tribunal, the appellant preferred an appeal to the Madhya Pradesh High Court. ... In consequence, the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed on the 23rd April, 1963.

facts.text: High Court confirmed findings of Election Tribunal on both points.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has confirmed the finding of the Election Tribunal on both the points. It has held that the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was valid

facts.text: Appellant claimed he was Dohar Chamar, sub-caste of Chamar, also called Mochi.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellants case was that he was a Dohar Chamar which according to him is a sub-caste of the Chamar scheduled caste. He urged that the said sub-caste was also called Mochi.

facts.text: Both parties led oral and documentary evidence on caste issue.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this plea, the appellant examined witnesses and produced documents, and as we have just indicated, respondent No. 1 also produced witnesses and examined documents

facts.text: Election Tribunal and High Court made concurrent findings that appellant not belonging to Chamar caste.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the question which arose between the parties for decision in the present proceedings is a question of fact and on this question both the Tribunal and the High Court have made concurrent findings against the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court declines to interfere with concurrent findings on caste.

anchor.surface_text: but in cases of this kind where the Tribunal and the High Court make concurrent findings on questions of fact, this Court does not usually interfere and after hearing Mr. Chatterjee we see no reason

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 examined 13 witnesses from Dohar caste who said Dohar different from Chamar, no inter-marriage or inter-dining.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 examined 13 witnesses belonging to the caste of the appellant. All of them asserted that they did not belong to the Chamar caste. According to their evidence, the Dohar caste was different from the Chamar caste.

facts.text: Kishanlal PW4, Secretary of Dohar Samaj started by appellant, appellant was Sarpanch.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst the witnesses examined by respondent No. 1, the High Court has attached considerable significance to the evidence of Kishanlal, P. W. 4., He was the Secretary of the Dohar Samaj started by the appellant himself. The appellant was then the Sarpanch

facts.text: Documents Exts. P.2 to P.5 signed by appellant in 1956 describe him as Dohar, not Chamar.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his oral evidence, respondent No. 1 produced certain documents, Exts. P. 2, P. 3, P. 4 and P. 5. These are all signed by the appellant and they relate to the year 1956.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds appellant does not belong to Chamar caste and was not qualified for reserved seat.

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question.

facts.text: Constitution Scheduled Castes Order 1950 issued by President under Article 341 specifies Chamar, Jatav or Mochi.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the notification refers to Chamar, Jatav or Mochi, and so, in dealing with the question in dispute between the parties, the enquiry which the Election Tribunal can hold

facts.text: Plea that Dohar is sub-caste of Chamar not acceptable under Article 341.

anchor.surface_text: The plea that though the appellant is not a Chamar as such, he can claim the same status by reason of the fact that he belongs to the Dohar caste which is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste, cannot be accepted.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated April 23, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 24 of 1963. C. Chatterjee, V. S. Sawhney, S. S. Kanjuja and Ganpat Rai, for the appellant.
This appeal by special leave arises out of an Election petition filed by respondent No. 1, Harikishan Singh, challenging the validity of the election of the appellant, Bhaiyalal,

Against this decision of the Election Tribunal, the appellant preferred an appeal to the Madhya Pradesh High Court. ... In consequence, the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed on the 23rd April, 1963.
On the other hand, the appellant urged that the election petition filed by respondent No. 1 was not maintainable inasmuch as he had not deposited the security of Rs. 2,000

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question. Incidentally, we may point out that the plea that the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste cannot be entertained in the present proceedings in view of the Constitution  Scheduled Castes  Order, 1950.

concepts.interpretation: Specifies castes like Chamar, Jatav or Mochi as Scheduled Castes for relevant areas; governs determination of Scheduled Caste status.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: jyaramnami. It is also remarkable that in Maharashtra in certain districts Chambhar and Dhor are included in the list separately. Therefore, we do num

concepts.unlisted_description: Presidential notification listing Scheduled Castes under Article 341

anchor.surface_text: This Order has been issued by the President under Article 341 of the Constitution. Article 341 (1) provides that the President may with respect to any State or Union territory, and where it is a State, after consultation with the Governor thereof, by public notification, specify the castes, races or tribes or parts of or groups within castes, races, or tribes which shall for the purposes of this Constitution be deemed to be Scheduled Castes in relation to that State or Union territory, as the case may be.

concepts.interpretation: President specifies Scheduled Castes by notification; cannot be varied except by Parliament; status determined strictly by list; sub-castes not included unless specified; can specify by districts/areas based on backwardness.
concepts.unlisted_description: Specification of Scheduled Castes by President; Clauses (1) and (2) quoted and applied

concepts.interpretation: Notification under cl.(1) cannot be varied except by Parliament.
concepts.unlisted_description: Parliament's power to amend Scheduled Castes list

concepts.interpretation: President authorised to specify by parts, groups, or areas/districts considering varying backwardness.
concepts.unlisted_description: Power to specify Scheduled Castes by reference to districts/sub-areas

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question.

concepts.interpretation: Candidate must belong to listed Scheduled Caste for reserved constituency seat.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard practice followed; no compelling reason shown to depart after hearing arguments

holdings.text: The appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts upheld after review of evidence; no basis to interfere

holdings.text: The plea that the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste cannot be entertained in view of the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950; determination of Scheduled Caste status is strictly by reference to the President's notification listing specific castes

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, we may point out that the plea that the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste cannot be entertained in the present proceedings in view of the Constitution Scheduled Castes Order, 1950. This Order has been issued by the President under Article 341 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 341 requires looking only at the specified list (Chamar, Jatav or Mochi); no permissible enquiry into sub-castes to modify list except special circumstances per precedent (B. Basavalingappa)

holdings.text: It is competent for the President under Article 341(1) to specify lists of Scheduled Castes by reference to different districts or sub-areas of the States
holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 341(1) text authorizes specification to parts, groups or areas within castes/races/tribes to account for varying backwardness across state regions

precedents.citation: B. Basavalingappa v. Munichinnappa Others, 1965 1 S.C.R. 316

anchor.surface_text: B. Basavalingappa v. Munichinnappa Others, 1 this Court had occasion to companysider a similar question. The question which arose for decision in that case was whether respondent No. 1, though Voddar by caste, belonged to the scheduled caste of Bhovi mentioned in the Order, and while holding that an enquiry into the said question was permissible, the Court has elaborately referred to the special and unusual 1 1965

precedents.cited_proposition: normal rule is that it is not open to make any modification in the Order by producing evidence to show that though caste A alone is mentioned in the Order, caste B is also a part of caste A, and therefore must be deemed to be included in caste A
precedents.cited_holding: enquiry into whether respondent No. 1 though Voddar by caste belonged to the scheduled caste of Bhovi was permissible due to special and unusual circumstances

outcome.relief_summary: No interference with concurrent findings; appellant held not belonging to Chamar scheduled caste and unqualified for reserved seat

anchor.surface_text: We must, accordingly, hold that the appellant does not belong to the Chamar caste and as such was not qualified to contest the reserved seat for the scheduled caste of Chamars in the Constituency in question.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, we may point out that the plea that the Dohar caste is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste cannot be entertained in the present proceedings in view of the Constitution Scheduled Castes Order, 1950. This Order has been issued by the President under Article 341 of the Constitution.

We allowed Mr. Chatterjee to take us through the material evidence and on considering the said evidence in the light of the criticism made by Mr. Chatterjee, we are satisfied that there is numberreason to interfere with the concurrent finding recorded by the Tribunal and the High Court on the main question of fact.
